results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Commodore 64/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, game manual and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

results.title: Three sisters and three ukuleles
results.creator_credit: T'Kido Titasey, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: T’Kido Titasey dedicates this story to his grandmother. Born a Torres Strait Islander, she never received a formal education but was taught about survival. After World War II, she set up a ukulele band with her two sisters. It became popular and The Mill Sisters travelled around the world and landed a recording deal. Gran’s resourcefulness and eagerness to try new things took her and her sisters on an amazing adventure and has been an immense inspiration to T’Kido.
results.creator_credit_for_label: T’Kido Titasey, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: T’Kido Titasey dedicates this story to his grandmother. Born a Torres Strait Islander, she never received a formal education but was taught about survival. After World War II, she set up a ukulele band with her two sisters. It became popular and The Mill Sisters travelled around the world and landed a recording deal. Gran’s resourcefulness and eagerness to try new things took her and her sisters on an amazing adventure and has been an immense inspiration to T’Kido.

results.title: Two laws. Part 2: Welfare times
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 2 of a 4-part innovative film entitled “Two laws” which deals with the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of their law. Describes the life of the Borroloola community under the welfare system of the 1950s to the present day. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.description: Part 2 of a 4-part innovative film entitled “Two laws” which deals with the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of their law. Describes the life of the Borroloola community under the welfare system of the 1950s to the present day. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Tracker [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer, Julie Ryan, South Australian Film Corporation and Vertigo Productions
results.brief_description: Set in the Australian outback in 1922 and filmed on location in the Flinders Ranges, South Australia, “The Tracker” tells the story of three white men and a First Nations tracker whom they employ in pursuit of a fugitive. The Tracker (David Gulpilil) is a First Nations policeman during a time in which trackers were employed to find suspects. He answers to The Fanatic (Gary Sweet), a cruel bigot who is hell bent on catching The Fugitive, a First Nations man accused of murdering a white woman. The Follower (Damon Gameau), is a naive young colonial policeman new to the job while The Veteran (Grant Page) is a world weary man whose kind nature is overridden by what he must do and how society expects him to treat First Nations people. The three white men are ultimately dependent on the silent, ever watchful tracker. When an interrogation of some First Nations people turns into a massacre, the balance of power shifts and assumed notions of truth and justice are thrown into question. While the film tackles the brutal treatment of First Nations people by white police, De Heer avoids a realist portrayal of graphic violence by cutting to paintings (by South Australian artist, Peter Coad) that represent the scenes of brutality and bloodshed. With its sparse use of dialogue, much of the film’s thematic content - about the displacement of First Nations peoples by white settlers, and conflict between white and First Nations systems of justice - is conveyed through songs written by Graham Tardif and performed for the film by indigenous musician, Archie Roach. David Gulpilil won an AFI Award for best actor for his role in the film. Written by Rolf de Heer ; cinematography by Ian Jones ; editing by Tania Nehme. Jointly commissioned by Adelaide Festival of the Arts 2002 and SBS Independent.

results.title: Rabbit-Proof Fence
results.creator_credit: Christine Olsen, Phil Noyce, Jabel Films, South Australian Film Corporation, Premium Movie Partnership and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ is based on the true story of three First Nations girls, Molly, Daisy and Gracie, who in 1931 were forcibly removed from their mothers and home in Jigalong, Western Australia, and sent to a settlement 2000 kilometres away to be trained as domestic servants and inducted into White culture. Upon arrival, the girls are instantly averse to their strange, rather grotesque new world, and decide to take matters into their own hands by attempting an escape and return home. Here begins the girls’ seemingly eternal, epic journey across the harsh Australian desert landscape, with all odds against them except for a rabbit-proof fence as their guide home. In a moving finale, they are reunited with their mothers and, significantly, their culture. Though it is a specifically Australian story (the Stolen Generations and the White Australia Policy), director Phillip Noyce tells it in such a way that emphasises universal qualities of tragedy and heroism. He opts for an even-handed portrayal of the past, steering clear of images of oppression or subjugation and any chastising of White Culture, and instead emphasises optimism and survival. The film is adapted from a book of the same title by author, Doris Pilkington, daughter of the real-life Molly and ‘Stolen Generation’ victim. Christopher Doyle’s photography and Peter Gabriel’s score give spiritual resonance to moments of emotional intensity, such as the tearing of children from their mothers, the crossing of a daunting barren landscape and the homecoming embrace between mother and daughter. Stars Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury, Laura Monaghan, Kenneth Branagh, David Gupilil, Deborah Mailman. Also includes the 35-minute documentary “Following the Rabbit Proof Fence” by Darlene Johnson.

results.title: The Last Wave [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, James McElroy, Hal McElroy and Ayer Productions
results.brief_description: In this atmospheric mystery thriller a young Sydney lawyer, while defending four First Nations men against a murder charge, is troubled by dreams and is drawn into an underground world, the intimations of an ancient civilization. Step by step a series of apparently random occurrences assume a disturbing pattern. The city becomes a facade for a place of ancient ritual. Cast includes Richard Chamberlain and David Gulpilil and features photography by Russell Boyd. Features a digitally restored soundtrack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Weir, James McElroy, Hal McElroy and Ayer Productions

results.title: Australian aborigines: police tracker
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “Modern social studies”
A First Nations man’s hunting and tracking skills and how they were learnt. Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land and produced in collaboration with Professor A.P. Elkin, Professor of Anthropology, University of Sydney.

results.title: Sons of Namatjira
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Keith Namatjira and his relatives paint in the style of his famous father, Albert and live in an artist’s camp on the outskirts of Alice Springs. The film highlights problems which the Namatjiras confront in their relationship with the world outside their community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
